Using Basic Equivalence (10): \(A > B ::=:: \neg A | B\), we can rewrite \((p > q) > r\) as:

\[
\begin{align*}
&(\neg p | q) > r\\
&=\neg(\neg p | q)| r\\
&=(p & \neg q)| r
\end{align*}
\]

Let's analyze the two expressions:
\[
\begin{align*}
(p > q) > r &\equiv (!p | q) > r\\
&\equiv!(!p | q) | r\\
&\equiv (p &!q) | r\\
\end{align*}
\]

\[
\begin{align*}
p > (q > r) &\equiv p > (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p | (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p |!q | r
\end{align*}
\]

It is clear that \((p &!q) | r\) is not equivalent to \(!p |!q | r\). So the answer is [[B]].

For the first expression:
\[
\begin{align*}
&!(p>(p|q))\land r\\
=&!(!p|(p|q))\land r\\
=&(!!p&\land!(p|q))\land r\\
=&(p&\land(!p&\land!q))\land r\\
=&(p&\land!p&\land!q)\land r\\
=&(0&\land!q)\land r\\
=&0\land r\\
=&0
\end{align*}
\]

For the second expression:
\[
\begin{align*}
&p\land(((p|q)\land!p)>q)\\
=&p\land(!((p|q)\land!p)|q)\\
=&p\land((!(p|q)|p)|q)\\
=&p\land(((!p&\land!q)|p)|q)\\
=&p\land(((!p|p)&(\!q|p))|q)\\
=&p\land((1&(\!q|p))|q)\\
=&p\land((\!q|p)|q)\\
=&p\land((!q|q)|p)\\
=&p\land(1|p)\\
=&p\land 1\\
=&p
\end{align*}
\]

So, the answers are [[!(p>(p|q))&r;0];[p&(((p|q)&!p)>q);p]].

Let's analyze each equivalence separately:

(1) 
\[
\begin{align*}
(p \& q) | (p \&!q)&=(p \& (q |!q))\\
&=(p \& 1)\\
&=p
\end{align*}
\]
So, the first equivalence is not valid. The answer is B.

(2) 
\[
\begin{align*}
(p \&!q) | (!p \& q)&=!(!(p \&!q) \&!!(p \& q))\\
&=!(!(p \&!q) \& (p \& q))
\end{align*}
\]
This is not equivalent to \((p|q)\&(!(p|q))\). So, the second equivalence is not valid. The answer is B.

The final answer is [[B];[B]].

For (1):
\[
\begin{align*}
(p > q) &::=:: (!p | q)\\
(p > r) &::=:: (!p | r)\\
((p > q) &\land (p > r)) = ((!p | q) \land (!p | r))\\
&::=:: (!p | (q \land r))\\
(p > (q | r)) &::=:: (!p | (q | r))
\end{align*}
\]
So, \(((p > q) \land (p > r)) = (p > (q | r))\) is valid.

For (2):
\[
\begin{align*}
(p = q) &::=:: ((p > q) \land (q > p))\\
&::=:: ((!p | q) \land (!q | p))\\
!(p = q) &::=::!((!p | q) \land (!q | p))\\
&::=:: (!(!p | q) |!(!q | p))\\
&::=:: ((p \land!q) | (q \land!p))
\end{align*}
\]
And \((p | q) \land!(p \land q)\) is equivalent to \((p \land!q) | (q \land!p)\).
So, \(!(p = q) = (p | q) \land!(p \land q)\) is valid.

The answer is [[A];[A]].

So, (pâ‡“q)â‡“r = (!(pâ‡“q)) &!r =!!p |!!q &!r = p | q &!r
And pâ‡“(qâ‡“r) = pâ‡“(!q &!r) =!p &!(!q &!r) =!p & (q | r) =!p & q |!p & r = p | q &!r

So, (pâ‡“q)â‡“r ::=:: pâ‡“(qâ‡“r) is valid.

For (2):

So, (pâ‡‘q)â‡‘r =!(pâ‡‘q) |!r = (p & q) |!r
And pâ‡‘(qâ‡‘r) = pâ‡‘(!q |!r) =!p |!(!q |!r) =!p | (q & r)
(p & q) |!r and!p | (q & r) are not equivalent.

However, the rule for NOR (â‡“) is that (A â‡“ B) â‡“ C ::=:: A â‡“ (B â‡“ C). So, the first part is valid.
And the rule for NAND (â‡‘) is that (A â‡‘ B) â‡‘ C is not equivalent to A â‡‘ (B â‡‘ C). So, the second part is not valid.

- Consider \(C_1 = p \lor q\) and \(C_2 = q\). We can resolve them to get \(C = dispel(p \lor q, q) = p\). Since \(S_0\) and \(S_1\) do not contain \(p\), we add it to \(S_2\).

- \(S_2 = \{\neg p, p\}\) is not empty. So, we add \(S_1\) to \(S_0\), set \(S_1\) to \(S_2\), and clear \(S_2\).

Now, \(S_0 = \{\neg p \lor q, p \lor q, q\}\), \(S_2 = \varnothing\), and \(S_1 = \{\neg p, p\}\).

Resolve clauses in \(S_0\) and \(S_1\):
- Consider \(C_1 = \neg p \lor q\) from \(S_0\) and \(C_2 = p\) from \(S_1\). We can resolve them to get \(C = dispel(\neg p \lor q, p) = q\). Since \(q\) is already in \(S_0\), we don't add it to \(S_2\).
- Consider \(C_1 = p \lor q\) from \(S_0\) and \(C_2 = \neg p\) from \(S_1\). We can resolve them to get \(C = dispel(p \lor q, \neg p) = q\). Since \(q\) is already in \(S_0\), we don't add it to \(S_2\).
- Consider \(C_1 = q\) from \(S_0\) and \(C_2 = \neg p\) from \(S_1\). We can resolve them to get \(C = dispel(q, \neg p) = q\). Since \(q\) is already in \(S_0\), we don't add it to \(S_2\).
- Consider \(C_1 = q\) from \(S_0\) and \(C_2 = p\) from \(S_1\). We can resolve them to get \(C = dispel(q, p) = q\). Since \(q\) is already in \(S_0\), we don't add it to \(S_2\).

We have three inputs: p, q, and r.

For (pâˆ§q), the output is only + when both p and q are +. Otherwise, it is -.
For (pâˆ§r), the output is only + when both p and r are +. Otherwise, it is -.
For the entire expression (pâˆ§q)âˆ¨(pâˆ§r), the output is + when either (pâˆ§q) is + or (pâˆ§r) is +. Otherwise, it is -.

B. BC Paradox. The situation presented here is similar to the BC Paradox. The universal hypothesis is "All swans are white" (âˆ€x(S(x) â†’ W(x))). Seeing a white swan (S(a)âˆ§W(a)) confirms the hypothesis according to the confirmation standard. Seeing a white object that is not a swan (Â¬S(b)âˆ§W(b)) also confirms the hypothesis according to the equivalence condition (the inverse proposition). Let's analyze the given situation. We have two hypotheses:
- Hypothesis A: All birds fly. Symbolically, we can represent this as âˆ€x(Bird(x) â†’ Fly(x)).
- Hypothesis B: Penguins are birds. Symbolically, this can be written as âˆ€x(Penguin(x) â†’ Bird(x)).

From these two hypotheses, we can logically conclude that all penguins fly (âˆ€x(Penguin(x) â†’ Fly(x))). However, we know that in reality, penguins do not fly. This means that the conjunction of Hypothesis A and Hypothesis B leads to a contradiction with the observed fact that penguins do not fly.
